John Lewis and many others fought so hard for the right to vote, and we must continue that cause to ensure every American has access to the ballot.

Sincerely,
Brad

In 2020, we lost civil rights icon and my personal hero, John Lewis. We must honor his legacy by continuing to demand the Senate pass the John Lewis Voting Rights Advancement Act‚Äîeven if it necessitates filibuster reform.

It‚Äôs clear we need federal action to combat the crisis happening at the state level, just as we did in 1965 when Congress passed the Voting Rights Act. Today, I am working to advance the next stage of voting rights action.

Legislation like this aims to curtail voting by mail, add voter ID requirements, place restrictions on voter registration, and aggressively purge voter files‚Äîall measures that disproportionately disenfranchise Black Americans.
Per the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, since the 2020 election, at least 19 states have passed voter suppression laws and more than 400 similar bills have been introduced in 49 states.
The push for transformational voting rights legislation in Congress is a cause we will continue to support tirelessly ‚Äì it‚Äôs common sense reform we must advance.

In 2020, Black voters turned out in record numbers. Now, states across the country have taken sweeping action to restrict access to the ballot ‚Äì seeking to disproportionately disenfranchise Black Americans in the process.
Yet remarkably, more than 50 years later, the struggle continues and the challenges today are as serious as at any time in our history.
A key aspect of the history of Black Americans is the fight for voting rights. It was a struggle achieved that achieved great progress in the 1960s. with the passage of the Voting Rights Act.
Each February, we celebrate Black History Month to highlight and honor the experiences and contributions of Black Americans throughout our country‚Äôs history.

So today, we are poised to make one of the biggest investments in domestic manufacturing in our nation's history. To create jobs. To prevent inflation. To make us resilient in the next crisis. And to ensure American companies lead the world in technological innovation.

Does this work? In 2009, the Energy Dept. made a $465 million loan to a tech company making a high-end electric sports car. Today, Tesla is one of America's most successful companies, after repaying that loan from taxpayers with interest. Our competitors do this, too.

So our bill creates an Office of Manufacturing Security and Resilience at the Commerce Department. We give it $46 billion to make loans and grants to bring home domestic manufacturing of goods and technology critical to our economic and national security.

Car prices rise due to a shortage of advanced microchips that come mostly from Taiwan, which is threatened by China. Solar panel components come from China's Xinjiang province, slave labor central. We're too dependent on others for pharma ingredients, PPE, battery tech, etc.

Thanks to last year's economic rescue package, Americans have money to spend. But global manufacturing has not recovered fast enough to meet  demand -- leading to inflation. Our dependence on foreign supply chains, especially originating in China, is also a security risk.

Last year, I started working with @AdamKinzinger and @RepLBR on a plan to fix our supply chains and bring manufacturing of critical goods and technologies back to America.
